headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Following up on the Midwater commentary. You have five Midwater rigs, and semis rolling off in the first half of 2011, two in Australia, the Epoch and the Patriot, February and January, then the General in Indonesia, Ocean Guardian, and the Confidence and
componenttext: Following up on the Midwater commentary. You have five Midwater rigs, and semis rolling off in the first half of 2011, two in Australia, the Epoch and the Patriot, February and January, then the General in Indonesia, Ocean Guardian, and the Confidence and Saratoga in the Gulf of Mexico. Is there any risk of those five rigs of rigs becoming warm-stacked, idle? What's the demand for those five rigs as they roll off early this year?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's always the risk of that. I would say the one that everyone needs to focus on is the Epoch. We've got a special survey coming up. And it's time to invest quite a bit of money on that rig just due to some age issues and we're still trying to get a h
componenttext: There's always the risk of that. I would say the one that everyone needs to focus on is the Epoch. We've got a special survey coming up. And it's time to invest quite a bit of money on that rig just due to some age issues and we're still trying to get a handle on that. So in all likelihood, that rig will be off contract and off day rate earning potential for that period. But at the same time, that should help the prospects on renewal of both the Patriot and the General in that region. And I guess the Falklands, we're really dependent upon some small operators who have raised money and whether or not they go or don't go, we've got a nice de-mobe to receive that will get us back to the North Sea, should they choose not to do that. But again, if you go into a de-mobe situation, for accounting purposes, we go to zero. But Mike, will you have any color on that?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the Saratoga, the one that Larry didn't comment on, we're continually talking to customers and we're in discussions right now regarding the Saratoga. So there's some interest on that rig also. So like Larry said, I think the biggest risk could possibly
componenttext: On the Saratoga, the one that Larry didn't comment on, we're continually talking to customers and we're in discussions right now regarding the Saratoga. So there's some interest on that rig also. So like Larry said, I think the biggest risk could possibly be the Epoch. The others, we're really confident on.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: And then could you give us a little bit more color on what's happening with the Ocean Monarch? You have it listed as going back on contract, or just, well, just as far as where it stands. Are you recognizing any stand-by rate with the force majeure and the outlook for getting that rig back to work?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We are in court. Our customer sued to try to get clarity on the force majeure issue. And we're not recognizing any income in the interim. We have an obligation to mitigate the damages. So we bid that out of the Gulf of Mexico. Right now, there are a coupl
componenttext: We are in court. Our customer sued to try to get clarity on the force majeure issue. And we're not recognizing any income in the interim. We have an obligation to mitigate the damages. So we bid that out of the Gulf of Mexico. Right now, there are a couple prospects for return to work on not Deepwater drilling but completions and other type of activity that we think has a higher likelihood of being permitted. But again, the Gulf of Mexico has this cloud over it of exactly when and how we're going to get back to work.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so as a follow-up to that, in the Gulf of Mexico from your customers, you really haven't heard any change of conversation or pace on permitting, no change from only a month ago, two months ago.
componenttext: And so as a follow-up to that, in the Gulf of Mexico from your customers, you really haven't heard any change of conversation or pace on permitting, no change from only a month ago, two months ago.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're working really hard on the issue of containment, which is a big part of their permit application. As you know, I'm sure there's two groups out there, and from my discussions with the customer, I'm sure Michael's as well, I think they're amazingly
componenttext: They're working really hard on the issue of containment, which is a big part of their permit application. As you know, I'm sure there's two groups out there, and from my discussions with the customer, I'm sure Michael's as well, I think they're amazingly upbeat on that. And so once they get over that hurdle, then the next hurdle is the actual application for permits and how the environmental standards go through. I believe that the vibe coming out of the regulators is that for certain of the operations that were in progress at the date of the Macondo incident, they would not have to apply for a new environmental permit. And so gathering around those particular rigs and operations, that would be everybody's thinking, that those would be the first rigs to go back to work. But there's still hurdles to go over, and then oftentimes you find that there's new hurdles you didn't know about when you get clear of the last one.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: And finally on the third option, on the new build rig, what will be the driver executing that third option? And can you extend that option if you need to?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the shipyards are pretty strict on a definitive date because there is, as you know, lots of interest out there. So we've got that through this quarter. Certainly, if -- and this is a low likelihood, but if we had some clear interest on our existin
componenttext: I think the shipyards are pretty strict on a definitive date because there is, as you know, lots of interest out there. So we've got that through this quarter. Certainly, if -- and this is a low likelihood, but if we had some clear interest on our existing fleet, then we would -- if in our mind, we weren't necessarily making that jump to having three rigs on spec, that would be a little bit easier. I can't always rule out that we wouldn't go that way. But the options are good things to have. And we've got it. Unfortunately, it doesn't go very long.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Ian Macpherson of Simmons & Company.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Question for you, Larry, or for Michael. The more [inaudible] -- even the more [inaudible] fixtures have been distorted lately because of the tough circumstances getting rigs out of the Gulf. So with the Endeavor and the [inaudible] and others, I guess, w
componenttext: Question for you, Larry, or for Michael. The more [inaudible] -- even the more [inaudible] fixtures have been distorted lately because of the tough circumstances getting rigs out of the Gulf. So with the Endeavor and the [inaudible] and others, I guess, we've seen lower rates than we might have otherwise expected. Is there -- do you have any clear read on what the real sort of structural underlying rate structure should be for those more deepwater rigs going forward? Are they being pushed down a notch on the ladder temporarily, or with more duration maybe beyond 2011 or can you even tell yet?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the longer you're out there, you'll have a better feel, but certainly based on the data out there, there is a definite discount that you take for more unit, primarily because of the cost of the boats. And then some of the perceived additional time i
componenttext: Well, the longer you're out there, you'll have a better feel, but certainly based on the data out there, there is a definite discount that you take for more unit, primarily because of the cost of the boats. And then some of the perceived additional time it takes to moor up on location. We have seen some jobs where the customer wants some more unit for certain advantages they bring, but there's not enough yet to figure that out. And as you indicated, you got the Gulf of Mexico with a cloud over everything until that gets resolved. It's hard to say where everything is. But I would expect, with the large number of DP [dynamic positioning] units that are being delivered or will be delivered that, that is going to be what sets the market, and we'll probably have to price off of that.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: I didn't quite get your answer before on the prospects for the Monarch and your expectation to work that rig in the Gulf versus international prospects.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: We'll, we've got some short-term prospects in the Gulf that I would rate as the highest likelihood, and that bidding out of the Gulf into various markets and closer is better than further would be the next likelihood. But we'll probably work in the Gulf of Mexico while we continue to bid, and then line up a bid to go overseas if we're successful.

componenttextpreview: Well, I mean those are our two Brazilian rigs, the Courage and Valor. And we do have a big mobe, but as Gary indicated, it's not in a number. But we are running high cost in the initial years to make sure that we're shipping in parts. We've done some repa
componenttext: Well, I mean those are our two Brazilian rigs, the Courage and Valor. And we do have a big mobe, but as Gary indicated, it's not in a number. But we are running high cost in the initial years to make sure that we're shipping in parts. We've done some repairs, and we would expect to do that. There's a high level of duty going into Brazil, and then we're hit by the dollar. So I'm not sure that, that's where everything is worldwide. But there is a trend for higher cost. There's huge demand for the steel people that you've got on those type of rigs, so costs are moving up.

componenttext: I'm chipping in for Arun Jayaram here. Just wanted to ask you a little bit more on the Gulf of Mexico, please. You've given some customer perspective, that's helpful. headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: At this juncture, based on the past history, I'm not willing to hazard a guess as to what they're likely to do in the future. They say, Secretary Salazar says that the administration is committed to offshore drilling. They want to make it safe. So I mean, that's their public statement. But so far, everything is continuing to move very slowly. But the customers, when I talk to them, although they get some frustration, I mean, they do have a good amount of optimism that they're making progress. So they're probably the best people to look at.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: My second question is regarding the downtime. Unfortunately, I'm somewhat of a pack rat and I have about three years of fleet statuses, and I went back, it seemed that your guidance for the past three years would indicate over 1,000 days of downtime in th
componenttext: My second question is regarding the downtime. Unfortunately, I'm somewhat of a pack rat and I have about three years of fleet statuses, and I went back, it seemed that your guidance for the past three years would indicate over 1,000 days of downtime in the upcoming year, and then for '11 and '12, where it's 744 and 530. So relative to the past three years, it seems like fairly muted guidance in terms of downtime, is that intentional? I mean, is that something where we see how the surveys line up and everything that things are going to come down relative to the past few years or is that just kind of maybe some convenient. . .

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: What you need to realize and everyone need to realize, the guidance that we give for downtime right now is what we know is going to be down. And so we're not going to have anything less than that unless we can shave a few days off of surveys. Things will
componenttext: What you need to realize and everyone need to realize, the guidance that we give for downtime right now is what we know is going to be down. And so we're not going to have anything less than that unless we can shave a few days off of surveys. Things will come up during the year. We will relocate rigs to other markets which will cause additional downtime, et cetera, et cetera. So the fact that we are giving less downtime than before is just the way that this works. We will give you everything that we know of, these rigs will be down during the year. We know that we'll suffer other downtime, particularly for relocating rigs from market-to-market. So kind of it is what it is.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: I guess your point would be that the risk is that things might move up as we learn more about what's going on the market and contracts change. But I guess my question was relative to this point in time in prior years, your outlook seems that there is less downtime on the horizon than we've seen the last few years. . .

componenttext: And we've said during the last few years, we've relocated a number of rigs to the markets. We've done upgrades, two rigs related specifically to contracts that we've achieved. We've got an extension going on down in Brazil for the Ocean Clipper, and we agreed to do some things for that. And then the upside, the Gulf of Mexico, continue to deny us work, and we would have more downtime that would flow from that.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: And of that, I think, primarily, is the first thing Larry pointed out, we knew in the past we were going to relocate rigs out of the Gulf. Right now, we're not anticipating relocating anything at this time. That will be an add-on, if we do.

componenttext: I have a question for you, a little bit away from the operation here today, on the tax effect. And wondering if I could get some more detail on why it affected your GAAP taxes. headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Much more complicated question than we can answer on the conference call here. All I can tell you is part of this is the tax rate is dependent upon the GAAP rules. A lot of the taxes that were related to this goes on APB 23 are now not going to be recognized until we bring those taxes back to the U.S. And the tax rate is as we calculated.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in the announcement of the tax deal, there was high focus on personal rates, and there was high focus on cap gain rates. And as you indicated, changes in the way businesses were able to expense deductions. But most of our drivers on the tax
componenttext: Well, I think in the announcement of the tax deal, there was high focus on personal rates, and there was high focus on cap gain rates. And as you indicated, changes in the way businesses were able to expense deductions. But most of our drivers on the tax rates were things that were not in the headlines but are routine kind of adjustments that the IRS makes and continues on and that was held up and had not been able to be passed and was bundled into the year-end tax bill, was my understanding.

componenttext: And so shifting back to kind of a market-related question, kind of more broadly, it seems there's a fair number of deepwater and ultra deepwater rigs rolling off of contract in the next several months. headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is Michael. I think in general, there is that risk. What we're seeing for that market is an uptick in particular in the second half of the year. A lot of the conversations we've had with customers and inquiries that we've seen have -- a lot are
componenttext: Rob, this is Michael. I think in general, there is that risk. What we're seeing for that market is an uptick in particular in the second half of the year. A lot of the conversations we've had with customers and inquiries that we've seen have -- a lot are focused in the third quarter of 2011. We think that there's going to be enough demand to utilize the supply that's going to be in the market. But again, there is that risk that the time doesn't work out and there's some short-term downtime for some rigs rolling off.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the, Diamond Offshore Drilling Second Quarter 2011 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Les Van Dyke, Director of Investor Rela
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the, Diamond Offshore Drilling Second Quarter 2011 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Les Van Dyke, Director of Investor Relations.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. And with me on the call today are Larry Dickerson, President and Chief Executive Officer; Gary Krenek, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Moe Plaisance, Vice President of Marketing; and Michael Acuff, Vice Presiden
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. And with me on the call today are Larry Dickerson, President and Chief Executive Officer; Gary Krenek, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Moe Plaisance, Vice President of Marketing; and Michael Acuff, Vice President of Marketing.
Before we begin our remarks, I sud remind you that statements made during this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements and are inherently subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected. Forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, in discussions about future revenues and earnings, capital expenditures, industry conditions and competition, basil drilling rigs laterals service, as well as management's plans and objectives for the future.
A discussion of the risk factors could impact these areas, and the company's overall business and financial performance can be found in the company's report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Given these concerns, investors and analysts should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements. The company expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates to forward-looking statements to reflect any change in the company's expectations or any changes in events, conditions or circumstances on which any forward-looking statement is based. After we have discussed our results, we will have a question-and-answer session, during which we ask that you please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up so we can open the floor to as many people as possible.
And with that, I'll turn the meeting over to Larry.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. We're pleased with our results to date a $1.92, after that includes in it a $10 million write-off related to a deferred mobilization on the Ocean Monarch that was resolved with our customer at the point in time that we signed
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. We're pleased with our results to date a $1.92, after that includes in it a $10 million write-off related to a deferred mobilization on the Ocean Monarch that was resolved with our customer at the point in time that we signed the commitments on 2 of our new. So that was a $10 million write-off, about $24.05 of earnings is included in that number.
The positives for the quarter that we would focus on was we had almost all-time low amount of downtime within our fleet. There were  only 24 days everyone were one rig in the shipyard's in Brazil work will business so we base impact of.
And all likelihood, our schedule shows that there will be multiple rigs in Q3 down from planned maintenance. And on the other side, the thing that we do work to control, we had a near record low unanticipated equipment downtime of only 65 days here in this quarter. It was down from 72 in the quarter before, which I'm also pleased with. So we got a nice trend going in that direction, and that obviously is something that we can control and generate more the revenue and more to the bottom line.
Our costs were up sequentially quarter-over-quarter, I'm pleased with our efforts and where we're spending money. We did start at the beginning of the quarter an offshore rig, which is reflected in there. And we've also put in place a retention program for selected employees on selected rigs, the one that were under the most demand, the highest skilled rigs covering the newer rigs.
And so those costs are in there. We would expect those to come forward back, but again, we're pleased with that. 
The other big thing is the amount of backlog that we were able to add, and all of that sort of came together in almost a 10-day period. So we were really excited about that. But the disclosures on the press release cover $1 billion. There were minor other minor ordinary course of business adjustments that really put a number at $1.1 billion of additional backlog. We're burning. In the quarter, we burned right under $900 million of revenue, which in effect, is backlog being burned off. So we were able to certainly replace that, and that ignores the $1.8 billion of backlog that we added to the 2 new, and I'll come to that.
But in the details of the rigs that we added additional timeline, I think most significantly, was down in brazil with our customer, Petrobras, one or new builds, the Ocean Valor and initially signed a contract at 3 years with Petrobras at $450,000 a day. We had included at that point in time our revision that would allow them to extend that to 5 years in return for a $10,000 perspective decrease in the dayrate, and they elected to exercise that at Ocean Valor. We had a similar provision in the fleet generation, Ocean Baroness rig, which we located down there, we extended that for an additional 2 years for a similar rate reduction.
And I think that's significant and I think it points out the demand that Petrobras has in the near term. And of course ,these extensions really don't kick in for 2 years or so. So it covers some years that '13, '14, so it's not just near term, but in the medium-term, they've got lots of discoveries down there. They need these type of large rigs to develop those, so that's a net positive.
At the same time, we had an opportunity to take the Ocean Yorktown, an intermediate rig, and put it into a bid in Mexico. We really didn't have another rig in the immediate area that could fulfill that job. And because it would be Petrobras' mutual benefit to relay them some near-term commitments, they elected, we negotiated to free up the Ocean Yorktown and move up the Ocean Yorktown fine to another mid water rig, the Ocean Concord.
Also, in Brazil, our big customer, OGX, put when your extensions in their larger rigs  the Ocean Star and the Ocean Quest. So significant development in our biggest market. We continue to have 16 rigs operating in that market and with all kind of backlog. So we're pleased with that.
Also, in Mexico, we are seeing a movement off of, frankly, some low-level activity that we've seen for the past year or two. And we have 3, in addition to the Ocean Yorktown arriving, we've got 3 jack-up jobs there, a slight extension on one of the existing rigs, a longer-term extension in the Ocean Summit. And in then the Ocean Titan, which have been working in the Gulf of Mexico, and which frankly down to the permitting issues, we were able to get a 777-day job there at a little over $100,000 a day. That will have to do some modifications to the Ocean Titan to get it qualified to go down in Mexico the summit that have been there for some period of time.
But we think that will pay out very quickly.
Then on our fleet status report that we released, we also indicated smaller extensions, which didn't include on the press release, the Ocean Nomad, extended in the North Sea, put that rig to work through the winter. And the Ocean Valiant continued to tackle on time in West Africa. West Africa is certainly an exciting market for there. One of the big event of the horizon is the our Ocean Confidence cobalt for highly anticipated well down there. So we will be, obviously, getting any updates on what's happening there. But we're there participating, and we think there's a  lot of upside in West Africa.
To go back to what's probably old news but happened earlier in the quarter, where we took both of our first 2 drillships that we had ordered and signed a combined 10 years was over 5 years per vessel at rights that generated $1.8 billion of backlog, and I think everybody can do the math. So those are our nice rates. And that excludes, we don't know where the rates were are going and all likelihood that a population will be also rolled into the dayrate contractually and certainly, from the count standpoint that rig will work. 
And the final thing I would point would be a continuation of our dividend policy. As indicated in the press release, we renewed our special dividend at the same rate that's been established now, I believe, 4 quarters, combined with our regular dividend. The 2 dividends combined, looking back to 2006 and paid out just a hair under $29 a value to shareholders. And again, continues to reflect our belief that dividends are important component of returning value to shareholders. And I always tell investors that we need, that you can't just look at our share price compared to competition and how that may perform and also, that you need to keep in mind, depending on how long you held it, at least some portion, and hopefully, our long term shareholders are the portion of that dividend just under $29 of value that you perceive.
So that concludes my own the remarks. And I will now turn it over to Gary Krenek to go through more details of our financials.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. Gary. For the second quarter, the most of the line items on the income statement came within expectations of what we expected, what we had talked about in our previous conference call. The one line item Larry alluded to that was slightly bal
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks. Gary. For the second quarter, the most of the line items on the income statement came within expectations of what we expected, what we had talked about in our previous conference call. The one line item Larry alluded to that was slightly bald was our contract drilling expense. We guided to between $360 million to $375 million is what we said the last conference call, and we came in at $388 million.
Larry said the biggest component of that overrun was the $10 million worth of deferred mode and preparation cost on the Monarch that we took a noncash charge for in the second quarter because of early termination of the contract on that rig.
I remind everybody that when we do move the rigs, we differ any costs occurring when that happens and amortize it over the length of the contract. So that was $10 million charge. We also had some weakening of the U.S. dollar, slight weakening for some of our own hit positions and foreign denominator expenditures. That cost us somewhere between $5 million and $7 million on expected, and then slightly higher some of the increase that Larry talked about. So if you think all those into account and adjust our actual numbers, we actually come right in the middle of the guidance that we put out last quarter.
Other than that, pretty much where we had expected. Looking forward to next quarter and the rest of 2011, I think the biggest thing is, again, Larry talked about, it is the downtime on our rigs that we expect in the third and the fourth quarters. Again, start to report that we released this morning to get the details of that. But just briefly, we have 4 rigs that will be undergoing a 5-year survey in the third quarter. We have 3 rigs in the fourth quarter undergoing surveys. We have 3 rigs in Yorktown, Monarch and that will be moving from one major area of location to another in the third and fourth quarters. They were at downtime. And finally, the Ocean Clipper will be down for a few days in the third quarter and the entire fourth quarter for some contractual upgrades that we have agreed to do with Petrobras 1.5 years, 2 years ago, when we extended the contract. We had been waiting for delivery of equipment and also for convenient time for both us and Petrobras gas service, and that kind of coming up. And if everything goes according to plan, and we start we're supposed to the end of the third, will be back on contract by January 1, 2012.
So this downtime for our rigs, we had very good downtime in the first half of the year. Just so happens that most of it is going to be back-end loaded in the second half of the year. The costs of some on both the mobile revenue line and will also affect our expense lines.
Looking at contract drilling expense for the third quarter. Again, we'll incur our normal daily operating costs that we were told everyone earlier in the year. To that, we do need to add some $22 million worth of amortized loan costs that we refer in the quarter. The go for survey cost each of those rigs would be somewhere between $4 million and $8 million, each 2 jack-ups and 2 semi-submersibles. The U.S. dollar, we're expecting to remain consistent. So we had another $6 million, to $8 million or were not normal cost of that.
And finally, our major expense cost for our major projects will increase somewhere in the $7 million to $10 million range in Q3, and then following also in Q4. And as we said before, this is normal. When we do our budgets in the fall of any given year, it takes the first quarter and part of the second quarter for us to write our ASP, quarter over equipment late on delivery. All of that stuff comes in, and we actually spend the money and record it in the second half of the year.
So if we had up those daily regular daily costs and the additional items that I gave you, that should come up to a third quarter contract drilling expense of somewhere between $395 million to $410 million.
Again, I caution everybody that the contract drilling expense only that does not include reimbursable costs. We do not budget for reimbursable costs. If you look at that, the reimbursable costs are virtually offset, dollar for dollar, with reimbursable revenues. And the revenue guidance that we give on our rig status report excludes any type of reimbursable revenues.
So when you're looking at on a project our earnings in the future, you really need to net those 2 line out, which we do.
For the rest of the income statement line items, the guidance remains virtually the same as it had in the last quarter. G&A, we expect continue to EBITDA at $70 million to $80 million per quarter. Depreciation, $101 million to $104 million per quarter, will be slightly up in the third quarter simply because of 92 days the next quarter versus 91 days in Q2.
Expense remains at about $22 million per quarter. Our effective tax rate at 21% to 24%, which is the same as we had guided previously. And finally, maintenance capital remains at $320 million for this year.
Additionally, we had some $475 million of down payments we made already in the first half of the year on the 3 new build ships that we did. Just for accounting purposes, that $475 million is not considered capital expenditures this year, but rather are is recorded in the balance sheet at a loan term deposit on our new builds. That will be flipped around when we actually take delivery of the rigs and will come out in the deposit account into our fixed assets.
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Larry.

The North Sea we're seeing work coming to the wintertime. We're getting that visibility now and securing that work. But to say that we're seeing a big uptick, we're just not at this moment.

But The mid water is to reduce now and you've got really Ocean Saratoga, which are coming up to survey, and about our Ocean Victory, which will serve as added. That's it. Everything else is deepwater market. So it's not taking place in a world where they're still the same number of rigs, so that you can measure things. Certainly, I think when we talk to customers in those markets, they seem to be very optimistic that the things aren't picking up. I don't know done that the government regulatory seems to be they're getting more certainty.

componenttext: It's supply outstrips demand, that's a fundamental of this business, We do see cost pressures, particularly on labor and on some equipment. I don't think it's gotten out of size. I mean, as you pointed out, rigs that are mid-water fleet, working in the North Sea, that we're renewing in low to mid-200, I mean, our operating costs are such that we're still enjoying 50% to 60% margin. So it is a profitable business from that perspective. It's not necessarily that profitable if you have to go out and place all the fleet in new construction costs, then they have for so we think shareholders earn money by having rigs, investing a company that has the rig that they previously acquired.

componenttext: We're optimistic but cautious. We're seeking we're seeing operators looking at their projects as we spoke about earlier, West Africa, we've seen increases there. headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm not going get protection on that. But I mean, there's a natural trend in the business that rigs return to work, things return to work a little bit long-term, that leads to opportunities to raise rates. And then, as you say, then there's a catalyst tha
componenttext: I'm not going get protection on that. But I mean, there's a natural trend in the business that rigs return to work, things return to work a little bit long-term, that leads to opportunities to raise rates. And then, as you say, then there's a catalyst that will some time occur and make thanks really explode. Among the catalysts is probably what you're saying, the sense from the operators that there's not going to be enough rigs to cover their needs certainly until some of the new builds arrive, and maybe not even then. Because a lot of the deepwater activity continues to generate demand from more rigs. You've got catalyst in Mexico's begins to take another primary in the jack-up stage. But still, that could contribute second rigs out of there. If Brazil moves, and then the Gulf of Mexico, if the permitting situation returns, that would be huge. The point I make again and again, which is not really relevant on this call, but that we, in this country, we get 9% unemployment and this industry has the ability to employ lots of people here in the United States without subsidy and paying among the highest blue-collar wages that are out there in the world. Our average rate in the Gulf of Mexico back when we had a number of rigs working out there is above $80,000 a day for a job 6 months old. So maybe somebody will finally decide that that's some positive side that they can take. So lots of positive catalyst that can come about.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Diamond Offshore Drilling Second Quarter 2011 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Les Van Dyke, Director of Inv
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Diamond Offshore Drilling Second Quarter 2011 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Les Van Dyke, Director of Investor Relations.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. And with me on the call today are Larry Dickerson, President and Chief Executive Officer; Gary Krenek, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Moe Plaisance, Vice President of Marketing; and Michael Acuff, Vice Presiden
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. And with me on the call today are Larry Dickerson, President and Chief Executive Officer; Gary Krenek, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Moe Plaisance, Vice President of Marketing; and Michael Acuff, Vice President of Marketing.
Before we begin our remarks, I should remind you that statements made during this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements and are inherently subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected. Forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, discussions about future revenues and earnings, capital expenditures, industry conditions and competition, dates that drilling rigs will enter service, as well as management's plans and objectives for the future.
A discussion of the risk factors that could impact these areas and the company's overall business and financial performance can be found in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Given these concerns, investors and analysts should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements. The company expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates to forward-looking statements to reflect any change in the company's expectations or any changes in events, conditions or circumstances on which any forward-looking statement is based. After we have discussed our results, we will have a question-and-answer session, during which we ask that you please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up so we can open the floor to as many people as possible.
And with that, I'll turn the meeting over to Larry.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. We're pleased with our results today of $1.92. Well, half of that includes in it a $10 million write-off related to a deferred mobilization on the Ocean Monarch that was resolved with our customer at the point in time that we
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. We're pleased with our results today of $1.92. Well, half of that includes in it a $10 million write-off related to a deferred mobilization on the Ocean Monarch that was resolved with our customer at the point in time that we signed the commitments on 2 of our new drillships. So that was a $10 million write-off. About $24.05 of earnings is included in that number.
The positives for the quarter that we would focus on was we had almost all-time low amount of downtime within our fleet. There were only 24 days covering one rig where we had a rig in the shipyard. It's where the Ocean Yatzy in Brazil doing some plastering work. We assume the ordinary course of business with the multiple rigs with minimal days impact.
In all likelihood, our schedule shows that there will be multiple rigs in Q3, down for repair and maintenance. And on the other side, the thing that we do work to control, we had a near-record low unanticipated equipment downtime of only 65 days here in this quarter. It was down from 72 in the quarter before, which I'm also pleased with. So we got a nice trend going in that direction, and that obviously is something that we can control and generate more the revenue and have more to drop to the bottom line.
Our costs were up sequentially quarter-over-quarter. I'm pleased with our efforts and where we're spending money. We did start at the beginning of the quarter an offshore rig raise, which is reflected in there. And we've also put in place a retention program for selected employees on selected rigs. The one that were under the most demand, the highest skilled rigs covering the newer rigs.
And so those costs are in there. We would expect those to come forward back, but again, we're pleased with that. 
The other big thing is the amount of backlog that we were able to add, and all of that sort of came together in almost a 10-day period. So we were really excited about that. But the disclosures on the press release cover $1 billion. There were some other minor ordinary course of business adjustments that really put the number of $1.1 billion of additional backlog. We're burning. And in the quarter, we burned right under $900 million of revenue, which in effect, is backlog being burned off. So we were able to certainly replace that, and that ignores the $1.8 billion of backlog that added to the 2 new drillships, and I'll come to that.
But in the details of the rigs that we added additional time on, I think most significantly, it was down in Brazil with our customer, Petrobras, one or new builds, the Ocean Valor and initially signed the contract at 3 years with Petrobras at $450,000 a day. We had included at that point in time our revision that would allow them to extend that to 5 years in return for a $10,000 perspective decrease in the dayrate, and they elected to exercise that, covering the Ocean Valor. We had a similar provision in the fleet generation, Ocean Baroness rig, which we located down there, we'd extended that for an additional 2 years for a similar rate reduction.
And I think that's significant, and I think it points out the demand that Petrobras has in the near term. And of course, these extensions really don't kick in for 2 years or so. So it covers some years that '13, '14. So it's an obvious near team, but in an immediate term, they've got lots of discoveries down there. They need these type of large rigs to develop those, so that's a net positive.
At the same time, we had an opportunity to take the Ocean Yorktown, an intermediate rig, and put it into a bid in Mexico. We really didn't have another rig in the immediate area that could fulfill that job. And because it would be Petrobras' mutual benefit to relay them some near-term commitments, they elected, we negotiated to free up the Ocean Yorktown and move the Ocean Yorktown time to another mid-water rig, the Ocean Concord.
Also, in Brazil, our good customer, OGX, put when your extensions on their larger rigs, the Ocean Star and the Ocean Quest. So significant development in our biggest market. We continue to have 16 rigs operating in that market and with all kind of backlog. So we're pleased with that.
Also, in Mexico, we are seeing a movement off of, frankly, some low-level activity that we've seen for the past year or 2. And we have 3, in addition to the Ocean Yorktown arriving, we've got 3 jack-up jobs there. A slight extension on one of the existing rigs, a longer-term extension in the Ocean Summit. And then the Ocean Titan, which have been working in the Gulf of Mexico, and which frankly down to the permitting issues, we were able to get a 777-day job there at a little over $100,000 a day. That will have to do some modifications to the Ocean Titan to get it qualified to go down in Mexico, that the Summit will not going to have been there for some period of time. But we think that will pay out very quickly.
Then on our fleet status report that we released, we also indicated smaller extensions, which we didn't include on the press release. The Ocean Nomad, extended in the North Sea, puts that rig to work through the winter. And the Ocean Valiant continued to tackle on time in West Africa. West Africa is certainly an exciting market for there. One of the big events on the horizon is that our Ocean Confidence in moving on location for Cobalt for a highly anticipated well down there. So we will be, obviously, getting any updates on what's happening there. But we're there participating and we certainly think there's a lot of upside in West Africa.
To go back to what's probably old news, what happened earlier in the quarter where we took both of our first 2 drillships that we had ordered and signed a combined 10 years, worth of work 5 years per vessel at rights that generated $1.8 billion of backlog, and I think everybody can do the math. So those are our nice rates. And that excludes mobilization. We don't know where the rigs were -- are going and all likelihood that mobilization will be also rolled into the dayrate contractually, and certainly from accounting standpoint, that's the way that our rig will work. 
And the final thing I would point out would be the continuation of our dividend policy. As indicated in the press release, we renewed our special dividend at the same rate it's been established now. I believe, for 4 quarters, combined with our regular dividend. The 2 dividends combined, looking back to 2006 have paid out just a hair under $29 value to shareholders. And again, continues to reflect our belief that dividends are an important component of returning value to shareholders. And I always tell investors that we need -- that you can't just look at our share price compared with the competition and how that may perform but also that you need to keep in mind, depending on how long you've held it. So at least some portion, and hopefully, for long-term shareholders, all of the portion of that dividend just under $29 of value that you perceive.
So that concludes my opening remarks. And I will now turn it over to Gary Krenek to go through a little bit more on the details of our financials.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Larry. For the second quarter, the most of the line items on the income statement came within expectations of what we expected, what we had talked about in our previous conference call. The one line item Larry already alluded to that was sli
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Larry. For the second quarter, the most of the line items on the income statement came within expectations of what we expected, what we had talked about in our previous conference call. The one line item Larry already alluded to that was slightly bold was our contract drilling expense. We guided to between $360 million to $375 million, it's what we said in the last conference call, and we came in at $388 million.
As Larry said, the biggest component of that overrun was the $10 million worth of deferred mobe and preparation cost on the Monarch that we took in a noncash charge for in the second quarter because of early termination of the contract on that rig.
I remind everybody that when we do -- when we mobe rigs, we differ any costs occurring when that happens and amortize it over the length of the contract. So was the $10 million charge. We also had some weakening of the U.S. dollar, slight weakening for some of our own hedged positions and foreign denominated expenditures. That costs us somewhere between $5 million and $7 million on expected, and then slightly higher because some of the labor increased, as Larry talked about. So if you take all of those into account and adjust our actual numbers, we actually come right in the middle of the guidance that we had put out last quarter.
Other than that, it's -- everything came in pretty much what we had expected. Looking forward to next quarter and the rest of 2011, I think the biggest thing is, again, Larry talked about, it is the downtime on our rigs that we expect in the third and the fourth quarters. Again, you can look at our rigs status report that we released this morning to get the details of that. But just briefly, we have 4 rigs that will be undergoing a 5-year survey in the third quarter. We have 3 rigs in the fourth quarter undergoing surveys. We have 3 rigs, the Yorktown, Monarch and Titan that will be mobing from one major area of location to another some third and fourth quarters. They will have downtime. And finally, the Ocean Clipper will be down for a few days in the third quarter and the entire fourth quarter for some contractual upgrades that we have agreed to do with Petrobras, 1.5 years, 2 years ago, when we extended the Clipper contract. We had been waiting for delivery of equipment and also for convenient time for both us and Petrobras that will take that we've got it serviced, and that time is now coming up. If everything goes according to plan and we start and we're supposed to at the end of the third quarter, we will be back on contract by January 1, 2012.
So this downtime for our rigs, we had very good downtime in the first half of the year. It just so happened that most of it is going to be back-end loaded in the second half of the year. The costs of some on both the revenue line and will also affect our expense lines.
Looking at contract drilling expense for the third quarter. Again, we'll incur our daily normal -- normal daily operating costs that we were told everyone earlier in the year. To that, we need to add some $22 million worth of amortized mobe costs that we will forward in the quarter. For 4 survey costs, each of those rigs will be somewhere between $4 million and $8 million each. We have 2 jack-ups and 2 semi-submersibles. The U.S. dollar, we're expecting to remain consistent. So we can add another $6 million to $8 million to our normal cost of that.
And finally, on major expense cost, for our major projects. It will increase somewhere in the $7 million to $10 million range in Q3, and then following also in Q4. And as we've said before, this is normal. When we do our budgets in the fall of any given year, it takes the first quarter and part of the second quarter for us to write our AFP, order our equipment, right on delivery. All of that stuff comes in, and we actually spend the money and record it in the second half of the year.
So if you add up those daily -- regular daily costs and the additional items that I gave you, that should come up to a third quarter contract drilling expense of somewhere between $395 million to $410 million.
Again, I caution everybody that the contract drilling expense only. That does not include reimbursable costs. We do not budget for reimbursable costs. If you look at that, the reimbursable costs are virtually offset, dollars-for-dollar, with reimbursable revenues. And the revenue guidance that we give on our rig status report excludes any type of reimbursable revenues.
So when you're looking at on a project -- our earnings in the future, you really need to net those 2 lines out, which we do.
For the rest of the income statement line items, the guidance remains virtually the same as it had in the last quarter. G&A, we expect it to continue to be at $17 million to $18 million per quarter. Depreciation, $101 million to $104 million per quarter. It will be slightly up in the third quarter simply because there's 92 days the next quarter versus 91 days in Q2.
Interest expense remains at about $22 million per quarter. Our effective tax rate at 21% to 24%, which is the same as we had guided up previously. And finally, maintenance capital remains at $320 million for this year.
Additionally, we had some $475 million of down payments we've made already in the first half of the year, on the 3 new build drillships that we did. Just for accounting purposes, that $475 million is not considered capital expenditures this year, but rather are -- is recorded in the balance sheet as a long-term deposit on our new builds. That will be flipped around when we actually take delivery of the rigs and will come out of the deposit account into our fixed assets.
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Larry.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we think that is a factor. It didn't hit us in this quarter. We are trying to take steps to minimize that. We've seen instances where we think in the past, we might not have had to take some period of downtime. We've had a little downtime here going
componenttext: Yes, we think that is a factor. It didn't hit us in this quarter. We are trying to take steps to minimize that. We've seen instances where we think in the past, we might not have had to take some period of downtime. We've had a little downtime here going into Q3 already on BOP stacks. It just hadn't hit us to that point yet. But certainly, in our future projections and whatnot, we're building in a little bit more downtime on bigger, deeper water rigs for BOP differences. We don't have a sense yet on what changes may happen in our mid-water fleet.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011

componenttext: Marketing guys, comment on it.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ian, this is Michael here. I would say you're correct. We continue to see a fairly flat to slightly improving. Again, back to your slightly comment. With Petrobras, we had an opportunity to add backlog on that mid-water fleet at similar margins. With Peme
componenttext: Ian, this is Michael here. I would say you're correct. We continue to see a fairly flat to slightly improving. Again, back to your slightly comment. With Petrobras, we had an opportunity to add backlog on that mid-water fleet at similar margins. With Pemex, it was a good opportunity. And they had some short-term drilling schedule issues that was able to benefit them also. But in general, as you look around the world, I think it's still fairly flat market. No pricing power to say. And we're continuing to be somewhat positive on it. The North Sea, we're seeing work coming through the wintertime. We're getting that visibility now and securing that work. But to say that we're seeing a big uptick, we're just not at this moment.

componenttext: Just wanted to, along the same lines of kind of more downtime and what is expected, on your third quarter estimate of the number of days, is that kind of forecasted somewhat conservatively? Or is there a significant over/under kind of range on that number of days that you've indicated in? I guess, 5-year survey could turn up a lot of new projects and perhaps weren't anticipated. Just comment and adjust to my question.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Gary, Robin. The number of days is our best estimate. We have a pretty good idea to simply coming up this quickly on as we've already have the engineers out there looked at it. You can always run into unexpected items, no doubt. But we're fairly c
componenttext: This is Gary, Robin. The number of days is our best estimate. We have a pretty good idea to simply coming up this quickly on as we've already have the engineers out there looked at it. You can always run into unexpected items, no doubt. But we're fairly confident with these numbers of days. Now can they go over an additional 10 days? Sure. We can find things. We have had times when we've got caught by weather. Just trying to get in and out of the shipyard. So again, it's a best guess we're comfortable with the burden in the fourth quarter could go over a little bit. We'll see. What becomes very difficult is when we tried to get some estimates for next year and the downtime for 2012 before we do those engineering studies. Those dates can certainly shift in the future.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. A follow-up then. I just appreciate your perspective on the North Sea market post the U.K. tax law change. And the Gulf of Mexico permitting phase, as you expected, going forward, and the rig, its impact on the deepwater rig market there.
componenttext: Right. Okay. A follow-up then. I just appreciate your perspective on the North Sea market post the U.K. tax law change. And the Gulf of Mexico permitting phase, as you expected, going forward, and the rig, its impact on the deepwater rig market there.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, the North Sea, we haven't really seen a big move one way or the other. Either offsetting that tax increase, has got to be the positive spread on grant over WTI, where we get interest and people that talk about wanting to drill. They don't really
componenttext: I guess, the North Sea, we haven't really seen a big move one way or the other. Either offsetting that tax increase, has got to be the positive spread on grant over WTI, where we get interest and people that talk about wanting to drill. They don't really always share all their thoughts and processes. But I think our sense is that this -- that the -- our oil price balances out those taxes in some instances. Beyond that, it really gets into production and dates that they have leases and things that aren't always clear to us, and they change a little bit. Permitting in the Gulf of Mexico, I think, has picked up. We've seen more permits being issued. They're primarily seen to be issued toward the deeper end of the spectrum rather than the mid-water. But the mid-water fleet has shown reduced now. Then you've got, really our Ocean Saratoga, which are coming up to a survey. And you got our Ocean Victory, which will service that. And that's it. Everything else is a deepwater market. So it's not taking place in a world where there's still the same number of rigs that you can measure things. Certainly, I think when we talk to customers in those markets, they seem to be very optimistic that the things are picking up. I don't know. Moe is even calling at the government regulatory on deep sea. It seems to be they're getting more certainty.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it seems to be getting more upbeat that they're looking at and it's been focused on the deepwater to get things back into the couple of customers looking up towards the future and they may be having moved some rigs back. If there's some positive..
componenttext: I think it seems to be getting more upbeat that they're looking at and it's been focused on the deepwater to get things back into the couple of customers looking up towards the future and they may be having moved some rigs back. If there's some positive...

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I guess the summary is the tone is improving and there we have more for permits going out to Noble. We're not near where were previous to that. And ultimately, I believe that the market has to have permits stacked up in their pocket because no one know
componenttext: So I guess the summary is the tone is improving and there we have more for permits going out to Noble. We're not near where were previous to that. And ultimately, I believe that the market has to have permits stacked up in their pocket because no one knows exactly when the wells going to end. It could be declared a no-show and they want to mobe all, and they need to be able to mobe this equipment rapidly and not go through another process. So we've got a way to go.

componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And my follow-up is on kind of some of your deepwater rigs, like the Valiant, which picked up the contract in West Africa. Can you give a little more color on what you're seeing in that market? It seems like rates have perked up a little bit there? Are you seeing any more term contract opportunities? Or is it still predominantly the kind of more well-to-well-type stuff?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Judd. On West Africa, we're really positive on that market. We're seeing, starting to extend on the term a bit. We're starting to see some 1, 2-year terms. We're definitely seeing some 6 months opportunities out there. So we believe it's a positive m
componenttext: Yes, Judd. On West Africa, we're really positive on that market. We're seeing, starting to extend on the term a bit. We're starting to see some 1, 2-year terms. We're definitely seeing some 6 months opportunities out there. So we believe it's a positive market, and we continue to see that the next few years as we see it today. So we're excited about the position of the Valiant. The Confidence has had a lot of inquiries also while it's over there. So, in general, everything is positive in West Africa at the moment.

componenttext: Okay. And there is timing more of an issue now for operators? Are they willing to pay a premium to get that type of rig today because there's maybe not other rigs available? They're willing to pay up ticket to something more immediate now, is that what's going on?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in the subsequent 10-day period, we didn't have justice. So I hope you can trend it out. But it seemed to sort of come together but there was a general theme there of people looking forward and having to grab capacity. Mexico's got issues with decli
componenttext: Well, in the subsequent 10-day period, we didn't have justice. So I hope you can trend it out. But it seemed to sort of come together but there was a general theme there of people looking forward and having to grab capacity. Mexico's got issues with decline of production, everybody knows about that. They've been going through a couple of years of bid processes, where they've not been getting the equipment that they need. So I would say there's that common theme. We're down in Brazil where huge, not decline, but huge anticipated upswings in available prospects to be developed. And it means that Petrobras needs to secure continued rigs to go down there, and this was, I think, a pretty good indication of that. And with Petrobras, they're looking by extending existing 2-year contracts that we're not even one year into, in the case of new build Valor. That really -- that shows some advanced planning more so than I think we were seeing now in Mexico. And then OGX, at the same time, as I think it's more the same. OGX is a little bit looking dealing with stuff a little bit closer to what's going on just because of the size of the company versus Petrobras. But I think all those common themes come together. But we didn't finish it saying, "Oh, boy, wait for the next 40 days."

componenttextpreview: Geoff, it's Michael here. I believe, what we're seeing in the pace has been in the recent quarter or the activity in the recent quarter is people are really starting to position themselves for '12 and '13. We're seeing that more inquiries. And it seems yo
componenttext: Geoff, it's Michael here. I believe, what we're seeing in the pace has been in the recent quarter or the activity in the recent quarter is people are really starting to position themselves for '12 and '13. We're seeing that more inquiries. And it seems you can -- it's a noticeable pickup, where especially in deepwater, we're seeing everyone trying to make sure they have the capacity they need come next year. And looking out in the '13. So I think in general, the theme is that though the story happened here in Brazil and Mexico, there's still everyone, still positioning themselves, and we're seeing an increase there.

componenttext: Okay. And if I could shift it to the downtime, Larry. I think you mentioned you're quite pleased with the unplanned downtime performance in the first and second quarter. headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- we then just flip the switch and put some price. We've got a number of preventive maintenance programs and programs designed to concentrate, replace BOP parts when we get an opportunity and those kind of things, all of which is designed t
componenttext: Well, we have -- we then just flip the switch and put some price. We've got a number of preventive maintenance programs and programs designed to concentrate, replace BOP parts when we get an opportunity and those kind of things, all of which is designed to reduce downtime. So I would say it's just incremental improvements in those programs. And I'm comfortable that we've got good programs going forward. I would not back that we could continue to sustain this. We talked earlier on the call about the issue of increased scrutiny on BOPs, and control systems around that will naturally result in a little bit more downtime there.

componenttextpreview: We think that continuing to add to our fleet, to have new builds makes a lot of sense. That is we had purchased new builds, as everybody knows, back in '09, Courage and Valor, and we shifted into the contracting with shipyards. But I can't say that we hav
componenttext: We think that continuing to add to our fleet, to have new builds makes a lot of sense. That is we had purchased new builds, as everybody knows, back in '09, Courage and Valor, and we shifted into the contracting with shipyards. But I can't say that we have a plan that will yield x number within so much time. We continue to evaluate it by way to use the cash, look at our contractual situation. We are very, very pleased with being able to put 2 units on long-term contract this early. And I think that certainly improves our outlook, as you indicated in there, but we're not at a point of saying.

componenttext: The Epoch -- the Epoch, I'm sorry, the rig. We haven't made a decision on Epoch. We've got 4 floaters that are idle to the Gulf of Mexico, 2 in the Far East. But we are looking at those, and we continue to look at those on some sort of upgrade plan and return to service for those rigs. They have reached the point that there was going to be substantial amount of money. But into them that we weren't quite sure where the market is heading with everything overhanging it for the 2 in the Gulf of Mexico. You've got the permitting problems that cover those. But those are -- that is an asset in an upside that exist within this company. As you mentioned, the Epoch or the Bounty being upgraded and coming out right next door to Singapore, where you would naturally do that. And then the Voyager ending there in the Gulf of Mexico would also be candidates.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Larry, I wanted to get your color on what you're seeing at the PEMEX. Obviously, PEMEX at a time when jack-up market was less robust, was attempting to try to upgrade the capabilities of their fleet. And obviously, given the improvement in the jack-up mar
componenttext: Larry, I wanted to get your color on what you're seeing at the PEMEX. Obviously, PEMEX at a time when jack-up market was less robust, was attempting to try to upgrade the capabilities of their fleet. And obviously, given the improvement in the jack-up market, we haven't seen a lot of bid activity. Hence, they face a pretty large adjustment in terms of demand. Do you see any opportunities, obviously, you have 4 stacked rigs in the Gulf of Mexico for them to switch stack then and maybe go down market? And maybe look at that rigs again? Obviously, with the accident a few years ago, I'm not sure if that's possible. I'm just trying to see if you could give us a sense of what PEMEX may do, given the fact to unlikely to meet their demand requirements, on the jack-up side?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, the movement today has been from -- the initial desire was for newer rigs. And I'm not sure that move that much down markets. They're now seeking older 300, 350-foot rigs that will do their work and substitute for that. I don't think th
componenttext: Well, as you know, the movement today has been from -- the initial desire was for newer rigs. And I'm not sure that move that much down markets. They're now seeking older 300, 350-foot rigs that will do their work and substitute for that. I don't think that map rigs, from the water-dept capacity, from the hook load capacity, from all the other invitation that exists from there are their preferred assets. And we're certainly not counting on the maps. Suddenly, everything around is all I'm seeing, when we go in Mexico.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Switching gears, Larry, obviously, you have a lot of backlog earnings. In Brazil, they have a tender out, but that again, we'll look at more rigs. What is your thoughts on assessing the potential of adding more rigs into Brazil? Or is there a
componenttext: Fair enough. Switching gears, Larry, obviously, you have a lot of backlog earnings. In Brazil, they have a tender out, but that again, we'll look at more rigs. What is your thoughts on assessing the potential of adding more rigs into Brazil? Or is there a saturation point where just from an overall portfolio standpoint, where you wouldn't want to get much bigger -- putting all your eggs into one basket? Just given your -- just want to get your color on that?

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we got one rig coming out. Then we -- I would certainly, I think having familiar with that. I can't rule that out, obviously. It's a big active market. We're a big participant there, with 2 big customers. And we would like to -- it's some market we'
componenttext: Well, we got one rig coming out. Then we -- I would certainly, I think having familiar with that. I can't rule that out, obviously. It's a big active market. We're a big participant there, with 2 big customers. And we would like to -- it's some market we're comfortable with. We'd like to add rigs there, and we're not going to rule that out but you're right, at the back of your mind. Our goal has always been about rigs around the world with a number of customers just so that we're diversified from any of the rest that might come to one customer or to one region.

headline: Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2011
